1500205011837542401.text: We couldn’t have asked for a more beautiful day in Mt Holly today. Thanks to the thousands of people who showed up on High St for the St Patrick’s day parade! https://t.co/8OcYClnJye

1499415125371064331.text:
It’s restorative to witness incredible young talent in our community. I'm going to wear a big smile because of these two all day. 
https://t.co/hpwoBvpZcH

1499415123546587139.text:
Take a few minutes this morning like I did to watch these videos of @ChampionCamryn of Lumberton and @itscolehallman of Monmouth county who earned tickets to Hollywood for @AmericanIdol. 
https://t.co/tQeuIOm6M9

1498812178249531397.text: I hope tonight is a moment to cut through polarization and rally the country together. Priorities of addressing mental health, stopping veteran suicide, tackling the opioid crisis, and cultivating service won’t fix all our problems but they could bring us closer together. END

1498812177255391235.text: Earlier this year, one of my neighbors at the local Mount Holly post office noticed someone having trouble getting to their car parked far away. When he realized the post office had no handicap spaces, he contacted my office and together, we were able to get spaces in place. 9/10

1498812175988703239.text: These students aren’t even in high school, but they saw a need in the community, and took action. To date they’ve recycled over 165 thousand batteries and educated over 2 million people about the importance of recycling batteries. 8/10 https://t.co/b53QyGQXVL

1498812174206214147.text: The state of our union isn’t just measured by these big, national issues, it’s also what we are doing in our own communities. Last month I met with a group of young students who started @recycleabattery, a campaign to educate and recycle batteries. 7/10 https://t.co/d8v6xl42cm

1498812173291823109.text: One thing I hear from constituents is that legislation won’t solve all of our problems. We need to take a step back as a country and find common ground that we seem to have lost. We need to remember the muscle memory of service to overcome divisions in pursuit of unity. 6/10

1498812171895070720.text: Now we must do better. Both parties supported bold action on stopping opioid crisis before and I have conviction that we could unite again in the wake of 100k lives lost.  I urge the President to pull us all together and unite on a real strategy to end the opioid epidemic. 5/10

1498812169961541633.text: Another vital issue I hope we hear tonight is the opioid crisis that’s ravaging this country. My community has been devastated. Too many of our friends and family have fallen victim to opioid addiction. We’ve lost loved ones because we haven’t done enough. 4/10 https://t.co/GbqsDDgY0L

1498812163087122432.text: Mental health is an epidemic across our society. Especially after 2 years of pandemic, many Americans are seeking mental health resources and we aren’t able to meet the demand. It’s time for us to step up and dedicate the resources needed to meet the moment. 3/10

1498812161883258882.text: This country has never truly lived up to the promises we made to brave servicemembers when they signed up. Many times, mental and physical health goes untreated. Many of us want to hear real commitment tonight to focus in on military/veterans mental health and suicide. 2/10

1498812161061183497.text: As we approach #SOTU, I’ve heard from many people that they're struggling with deep levels of uncertainty in their lives. They yearn for an agenda that can unite like tackling mental health and military/veteran suicide. Stopping opioid crisis. Things we can all get behind. THREAD

1498282957869617153.text: Appalling Russian missile attacks targeting civilian areas just now killed scores of Ukrainians. These are war crimes taking place as “peace talks” begin today. Need ceasefire immediately if talks are to be taken seriously.

1497936402767654914.text: The X factor in war is the will the fight. Legends are being made in Ukraine right now. Regular Ukrainians are stepping up the fight for their country and their freedom. It’s one of the most inspiring thing I’ve ever seen. END https://t.co/wIyR2yiSlz

1497936398543904771.text: Ukrainians pay close attention to the response of the world. They gain strength/encouragement when they read about countries sending weapons or large protests. The decision yesterday to start blocking Russia from Swift was a huge boost. They feel the world is behind them.8/9

1497936396962652163.text: I asked Ukrainians if President Zelensky is trusted and admired. Response was “like no other leader in the world”. He stayed to fight. They watch his videos to confront themselves while they take shelter in subway stations. His leadership is massive factor in morale of nation.7/9 https://t.co/ZVKm5nXQxe

1497936392575455232.text: Few pictures are more widely circulated among Ukrainians than photos of destroyed Russian tanks. Ukrainian soldiers filming themselves with abandoned tanks talking about the cowards who fled. Video of Russia soldiers begging for mercy and saying they didn’t want to do this. 6/9 https://t.co/EZwK0DA8sf

1497936388465086464.text: Kremlin supposedly reporting only 1 death of Russian soldier. Ukrainians reporting that number is over 4,000 Russians killed. Ukraine set up a hotline for Russian mothers to call to find out about their sons. 5/9 https://t.co/Ceh1L9OrGl

1497936383708741633.text: Multiple Ukrainians proudly told me about photos of unarmed Ukrainians standing in front of tanks and armored convoys to stop Russian advances. Gives them a sense of power of an individual. Each Ukrainian can do a lot. 4/9 https://t.co/l9iDi9DB6F

1497936375412264960.text: Pictures of women taking up arms and making Molotov cocktails are spreading wide and fast, giving Ukrainians a strong sense of people doing their part. 3/9 https://t.co/NKEE6zBtnB

1497936364624617477.text: Legends are emerging from the battles. Story of this Ukrainian soldier who died while blowing up a bridge to stop Russians from advancing was lionized by President Zelensky in a speech calling him a hero. 2/9. https://t.co/hFDJ90ULfu

1497936363030827017.text: After a long battle through the night, Ukrainian forces just declared victory in defending Kharkiv (2nd largest city in Ukraine) from Russian forces. The flag flies above the city. Word of this victory spread across country and Ukrainians tell me that morale is sky-high.THREAD https://t.co/uG4jgCDkfw

1497698145685237763.text: I’m glad we are finally taking some action on Swift, but I believe we need to go much bigger in using Swift to isolate Russia. Let’s keep pushing. https://t.co/APiMRErUIT

1497624186856132609.text:
A week ago I met Kyiv mayor Klitschko and he shared a story. As former boxer he held up open palm and said each finger is strong. Then he made a fist “together they are stronger than they can ever be on their own”

Now he fights alongside Pres Zelensky and Ukrainians, like a fist https://t.co/S0UgwF0ULI

1497568226972213251.text: Need resupply of ammunition and medicine and for west to take additional steps like blocking Russia from Swift. They say they are doing everything they can to stop the Russians and ask us if we are doing the same. Let’s be inspired by their courage and step up to do more. END

1497568226015948800.text: Courage of Ukrainian people is extraordinary. Hearing about people taking on Russian tanks with Molotov cocktails. But they need help now. They don’t know what next 24 hours will bring and if they can last another night. Even if they lose Kyiv, they promise to keep fighting.6/7

1497568225126723585.text: Every minute people are joining Territorial Defence Units across Ukraine. They say they need medicine and ammunition and are begging for help. They are calling for more Javelin missiles to take out Russian tanks and point to dozens of tanks destroyed so far. 5/7

1497568223910318083.text: But people report Russia is picking up the pace today. Full on attacks in Chernihiv. Bombings in Kharkiv. Helicopter raining fire on Kherson. In Kyiv Russians reportedly attacking a dam at reservoir that if destroy would cause catastrophic flooding and loss of life in city. 4/7

1497568222916366339.text: Ukrainians sense some weakness in Russian forces. Word spreads fast of major loss of Russian life. Russians reportedly running low on food and resorting to looting. Trucks/tanks running out of diesel. Unsure what all is true but reports are boosting Ukrainian morale. 3/7

1497568222060679171.text: Ukrainians say the shock they experienced on first day of war wore off yesterday; that they now have lost any hesitation they might have had for self-defense. They are fully ready to take on Russians. Regular people are lining up on streets of Kyiv to get weapons/ammunition. 2/7

1497568220030509058.text: People in Kyiv tell me they cannot describe the feeling of waking up and still having control of city. It’s not quite relief as they know today will be another brutal fight. They were so fearful they would lose their capital overnight. One day at a time they tell me. THREAD https://t.co/dCUhbU2l0E

1497311088358137866.text:
As a former high school yearbook editor, this makes me so happy to see. Congrats Ketanji Brown Jackson on your nomination. 

“I want to go into law and eventually have a judicial appointment,” Ketanji Brown Jackson wrote in her 1988 Miami Palmetto Senior High School yearbook. https://t.co/jN29IsNypO

1497020719896563713.text: Today is Day 1 and all of us were shocked by Putin’s aggression. But there will be more days ahead. Let’s promise to not grow numb to this violence. Putin wants this to become normalized. We cannot become apathetic to war crimes of a dictator. We’ve learned that lesson before.END

1497020717610713090.text: This is going to inflict real pain across all of Russia that Putin cannot ignore. His rainy day funds can only withstand so much. Many of us in both parties are ready to go even further and hope that the Admin are able to push European partners to do so. 9/10

1497020716490838018.text: There is wide agreement across political parties to pose immediate costs for Russia, isolate them, and degrade their ability to destabilize further. Admin highlighted that new sanctions/financial actions target nearly 80 percent of all banking assets in Russia. 8/10

1497020715333160983.text: Ukrainian forces were seen bravely fighting back all across the country. But can they withstand more ground fighting if Russia goes after multiple population centers? Do they have forces and resources to both protect Kyiv and the rest of country at the same time? 7/10

1497020712258838536.text: While in this briefing I also saw the Ukrainian President call his country to arms and mobilize adult males to the fight. Men 18-60 prohibited from leaving the country. But this mobilization takes time. Russia is moving on Kyiv now. Mechanized forces just 20 miles away.6/10

1497020710811836419.text: We need to do everything we can to keep up fighting capacity and will of Ukrainian forces. I heard bipartisan voices reinforcing that desire. US/Partners looking to resupply Ukrainian forces, but that will get more difficult as more territory is lost so we need to move fast.5/10

1497020709494796291.text: Putin wants a fast/decisive operation that cuts off Kyiv ASAP. Ultimately, biggest determining factor of whether Putin can be stopped is if forces face stiff opposition by Ukrainian forces that raises casualties/hinders speed. If he gets bogged down, calculations can shift.4/10

1497020708253175824.text: This assessment breaks my heart as it seems unavoidable that the Ukrainian people like the family in the above video are going to face serious suffering. This was Putin’s war of choice. Surreal that one person can single-handedly unleash such destruction and misery.3/10

1497020706692939778.text: Big takeaway from briefing: This is day 1 of phase 1 of what is expected to be long major operation. Russian plan expected to surround/isolate Kyiv, lay siege to city and overthrow gov. Russian forces approaching from multiple directions have significant armor and firepower.2/10

1497020704617013248.text: As we just received White House’s briefing, someone sent me this video. I’m watching this father say goodbye to daughter as I listen to SecDef say what we saw today was just the beginning. Told to expect major Russian ground forces to start to move on cities in coming days.THREAD https://t.co/8VnEM7nMHR

1496914215365451783.text: Thank you to the tens of thousands of Russian people who are bravely standing up to Putin today. Many are being arrested in protests all over Russia as we speak. Know that your voice is necessary and powerful. https://t.co/FS1WM8u6ku

1496872696541757447.text: Everything is moving fast and I’ll try to keep providing updates. No one knows yet full extent of war, but one thing clear an extraordinary number of lives of innocent people are at risk. Even if we don’t know people in Ukraine, I beg us to not turn blind eye to this violence.END

1496872694826127369.text: As of now, people I talk to say electricity, Comms, utilities like water haven’t been shut off yet, though I’m hearing other reports of internet outages. There were serious concerns that Russia would do cyber attacks to cripple Comms, air traffic etc during first wave attacks.8/9

1496872693534240772.text: Russia forces are taking casualties but we don’t know how many yet. Ukrainian forces are fighting back. Reports of number of Russian tanks/aircrafts hit. Russia will do everything it can to hide the toll this takes on their side so as not to lose support from Russian people.7/9

1496872691864899588.text: They said “full scale war” movements by Russians happening from north, east and south that leaves no paths for retreat. Northern parts of Ukraine being attacked from multiple positions including from Belarus.6/9

1496872689939718150.text: Critical port of Mariupol in Sea of Azov also under assault from land and sea. In addition to sea ports, airports are also the major targets of initial assaults. Reports of explosions and attacks on multiple airports across the country including one near Kyiv.5/9 https://t.co/vlMWbemqTm

1496872681245147137.text: Looking like one of the biggest initial battles will be for control over strategic port city of Kherson that is key to controlling the Dnieper River. Russian forces coming up from Crimea.4/9 https://t.co/jWnVkX4G0a

1496872673384689665.text: Instead they tell me to think of many of these initial assaults in terms of controlling sea and airports among other critical infrastructure. People still in utter shock that Russian forces conducted amphibious landing in Odessa.3/9

1496872668427079682.text: I asked how widespread the violence is. They reinforced several times not to think of this invasion as moving west from Russia linear through Ukraine. Attacks were happening all the way in western Ukraine likely by Russian cells who were already pre-positioned in those areas.2/9

1496872665491320833.text: Just got off phone with Ukrainians who say situation is worse than what’s reported. Some fleeing/amassing at Poland border. Others, especially those w/o cars, are taping windows, hunkering down with wet blankets in case of shelling as air raid sirens go off in Kyiv.THREAD

1496838640768589829.text: Overnight, Russia declared war and attacked a free, sovereign nation of 44 million people. Today we must put politics aside, unite as a country and a globe against this despicable act of war. Must be unequivocal in standing with Ukrainian people. No one can take Putin’s side. https://t.co/jU4nEfLNuY

1495791695174279175.text: It’s been amazing to see so many Americans compete at the highest level in Beijing. Special shout out to @KellyCurtisUSA, @GoetzKimi, @CharlieVolker, and Kenny Agostino for representing NJ and making all of us proud 🥇

1495051787614760965.text:
Kyiv mayor also shared metaphor he learned as a former professional boxer. He held up his open hand and said each finger is strong. Then he made fist and said, but together as a fist, the fingers are much stronger than they could ever be on their own. END
https://t.co/kt5pkeLal9

1495051786083872772.text: We gather here in Munich 600 miles from Ukraine border, the distance of Atlanta to DC. The Mayor of Kyiv came here pleading for help and reinforced that this was a time for our actions to rise to the level of our rhetoric about solidarity and reliability. 10/11

1495051784833929223.text: So often we frame the main contours of international clashes as one between democracies and autocracies. But the conversations here in Munich help show that the question of our time might be: will we stand up together to defend the rules-based system globally and at home. 9/11

1495051783550472202.text: We yearn for “normalcy” but what we often mean is that we want reliability. We want predictability. Solidarity breeds reliability and predictability and seeks to contain the unimaginable. Solidarity with other nations in a rules-based system is what hedges against anxiety. 8/11

1495051782371876866.text: RELIABILITY:  I can feel anxiety across the crowd in Munich. It has similarities to anxiety in my home district in NJ. Anxiety in both cases is rooted in unpredictability of our era. We live in a time when unimaginable is reality. Whether pandemic, Jan 6, war in Europe. 7/11

1495051781084270603.text: SOLIDARITY: Word everyone in Munich seems to be using to describe what is needed is solidarity. Whether in context of Ukraine, NATO, democratic states, or other arrangements. This focus on is critical. But I’ve been asking what is it about solidarity that is so powerful? 6/11

1495051779481948161.text: German foreign minister echoed concerns of breakdown of order. She asks, Are we living in age of helplessness? We are not helpless, she concludes. We draw our strength from action. But how do we act in a way that fights against hopelessness? What does that actually mean? 5/11

1495051778257305603.text: BREAKDOWN OF ORDER: Many people here talk about “breakdown of order.” UN SecGen said Russia crisis is example of challenge we face when rules of global order are tossed aside. He said challenges of miscommunication and miscalculation are higher than ever in this environment. 4/11

1495051777053446146.text: The conference chair said this is in his opinion the most important gathering of MSC ever. It’s not just that crises have become more intense/numerous. He reiterated theme of apathy and need to “unlearn helplessness”. What is creating this vivid sense of helplessness? 3/11

1495051775832993801.text: LET’S UNLEARN HELPLESSNESS: These 3 words flashed on screen as conference opened. This intrigued me. In a room full of world leaders, it says something about magnitude of challenges we face that leaders need to guard against feeling overwhelmed and descending into apathy. 2/11

1495051772632645637.text: As I walk up streets of Germany today where world leaders gather for the Munich Security Conference during perilous time, it’s clear that Russia/Ukraine is first on agenda. But as I talk more with people here, I sense a deeper worry about the world is also on their minds.THREAD https://t.co/COXD9RzSdZ

1494806140697337856.text:
Want an easy but important way to help save lives?  Hospitals are experiencing the biggest shortage of blood in a decade. Take a moment and go donate if you can. https://t.co/3OfU9V64vl 

Find a place to donate: https://t.co/Mc8oBSAo92

1493986144668766210.text:
I’m energized by the strong response to my new legislation banning Congress, President, VP, Cabinet/senior exec, Supreme Court Justices/judges, and others from owning stock. We need to restore trust everywhere and create a single standard of integrity.
https://t.co/4ZTJfut7t5

1493380507995938819.text: We aren’t asking for miracles. We know there are no easy solutions. No single bill or exec action can solve this. And it will take time. But we are asking for sustained attention and genuine commitment to not let the complexity of the problem prevent us from trying to fix it.END

1493380507333185542.text: Let us mourn the loss of these victims and others we lost. Let us support their families and communities. And let us come together and finally develop a comprehensive implementable strategy to tackle these problems and provide communities with resources to protect each other.8/9

1493380506649600004.text: And that’s just from NYC. All over country we have seen attacks spiking. AAPIs are tired of seeing constant news of attacks, hearing pledges of support, but then not hearing enough follow up on what more can be done to help. We need more than GoFundMe campaigns and vigils. 7/9

1493380505529688070.text:
On New Year’s Eve last year, Yao Pan Ma died after being attacked earlier in the year so brutally that he was in a coma for nearly 9 months before succumbing to his extensive injuries. 6/9
https://t.co/YQwia9Uo1j

1493380504736997376.text:
Just last week a Korean diplomat walking around in NYC was attacked on the street. 5/9
https://t.co/jkBmhN5ZrL

1493380503914917896.text:
AAPI community has every right to feel hurt and scared. Just a few weeks ago Michelle Alyssa Go was pushed in front of a subway train. 4/9
https://t.co/bqW0fZquJe

1493380503080157193.text: Yes we passed the COVID-19 HateCrimes Bill, and that is a critical step forward, but it’s not enough. We need to hear from DOJ and others about what they have done since to implement the law. What other tools else do they need? How do we tackle mental health and other factors?3/9

1493380501603856388.text: It’s been nearly a year since the horrific murder of 8 people including 6 AAPI women in Atlanta. AAPI communities across the nation deserve to honestly hear what all has actually changed in the past year to make them safer and what is the plan to keep improving. 2/9 https://t.co/L2x0Kqzvfx

1493380494054113280.text:
I feel sick to my stomach after hearing about murder of another AsianAmerican. 35 y/o Christina Yuna Lee. Man followed her into apt building. People heard scream and found her dead in her bathtub. Pain in AAPIcommunity is as raw as I’ve ever seen it.THREAD
https://t.co/VonUEfxq7l

1493193352656953345.text: Our country is at its best when we support one another, when we grieve together after tragedy strikes, and when we work together to realize the change we want to see in the world. These young men and women have set the example and it’s on us to follow it.

1493193350635212804.text: Let’s also honor the families of the victims and the survivors. I’ve had a chance to meet a number of them and have been humbled by their incredible poise in channeling their pain into advocacy, seeking to compel this nation to act. https://t.co/4M0jEYuiPc

1491426901495529475.text: We cannot fix our democracy and heal this country if we don’t have trust. We suffer from an enormous trust deficit right now. I often say the opposite of democracy is apathy. Apathy is prevalent when trust is absent. Let’s take bold action to restore trust. END

1491426899767459840.text: OUR OATH: When we swear oath into office, we say we “bear true faith and allegiance” to the Constitution. We state we are taking “this obligation freely, without any mental reservation.” We have no “purpose of evasion.” It’s critical to show that we are living up to this.14/15

1491426898542723074.text: Regardless of trust I have in many colleagues, we cannot ignore the fact that vast majority of Americans feel otherwise. Bold action to get away from whac a mole approach would reshape nature of the debate and reset the foundation upon which public service and trust rests. 13/15

1491426897175408641.text: There is real momentum here to address stocks in Congress. I greatly respect what some of my colleagues already proposed and support their efforts. Let’s keep working together. Urge us to consider expanding scope to Executive and Judiciary too and conflicts of interest.12/15

1491426895790952448.text: BAN ON CORPORATE BOARDS: Did you know Members of Congress are allowed to sit on corporate boards while still in office? Our oath to the Constitution should not be brought into question by having fiduciary duties to corporations. Let’s just cut out the ambiguity. 11/15

1491426894067408896.text: BAN ON OUTSIDE EMPLOYMENT/INCOME: Being a Member of Congress is a full-time job. It deserves our full and undivided attention. American people want to know we are 100% focused on them. 10/15

1491426892712640512.text: BAN ON LOBBYING: We also don’t want Members of Congress taking actions in office that are meant to set them up with lucrative opportunities to capitalize on their connections. Creating a ban on post-Congress lobbying for profit would cut off this concern. 9/15

1491426889550172161.text: PUBLIC TRUST: With diversified mutual funds, the public would know exactly what gov officials know about their investments, whereas blind trusts would move the public’s knowledge further into the dark. Even Mitch McConnell advises Members to do diversified mutual funds. 8/15

1491426888266686469.text: MAXIMIZE TRANSPARENCY: An elegant way to avoid conflict of interest is to require investment in diversified mutual funds rather than allowing stock trades through blind trusts. This would allow maximum transparency and sunlight while still allowing investment in markets. 7/15

1491426886723203072.text: CONFLICT OF INTEREST: With knowledge of blind trust contents, Members could still take votes/actions that benefit them. I ask colleagues who support blind trust methods to consider requiring liquidating assets before setting up blind trust to minimize conflicts of interest. 6/15

1491426884533764099.text: BLIND TRUSTS AREN’T FULLY BLIND: One problem is that Congressional blind trusts don’t require Members to initially liquidate holdings and have blind trust reinvest without Members’ knowledge. As a result, Members know the initial contents of trust and get updates on trades. 5/15

1491426882193362948.text: STOP STOCK OWNERSHIP: Much debate so far has been about blind trusts. Blind trust is better than status quo, but it doesn’t stop individual stock ownership or trading on your behalf. It helps address insider trading concerns, but still leaves real conflicts of interest. 4/15

1491426880444329984.text: In same way Members of Congress should not profit on their service, we should not forget about President, Cabinet Secretary, Supreme Court Justice, etc. Right now, there are no rules stopping any of these positions from owning/trading individual stocks. This should change. 3/15

1491426876946284545.text: The Constitution is sacred, and any job created by the Constitution or appointed by one calls for sacred trust. But trust from American people in Gov is so low that we must make the strongest effort to restore. Trust is shaken not just by Congress, but across all government. 2/15

1491426875323088896.text:
I love energy to ban stock trades in Congress and I’m now announcing new bill to create single standard across 3 branches to stop President Cabinet Congress Judges from owning individual stocks. President & others cannot have conflicts of interest.THREAD
https://t.co/NqmE1OGW3V

1489264703754805252.text: Nothing can ever balance the brutality of genocide. While we work to stop Al-Qurayshi and others from killing, we must recommit to helping those who survive. While we read news of Al-Qurayshi’s demise today, let us focus on remembering those lost to the senseless violence. END

1489264702475567115.text:
While ISIS threat is lower than its heights in 2014/2015, they have still caused tremendous havoc and devastation and still pose a threat to this day. Justice can never be brought to the Yazidis and others who suffered at the hands of Al-Qurayshi. 13/14
https://t.co/9tGdbnQxil

1489264700990889985.text: Last night, under cover of darkness, brave US servicemembers risked everything to target Al-Qurayshi. Flying by helicopter into Syria & for two hours battled Al-Qurayshi and other fighters in an effort to avenge those lost and prevent future attacks. 12/14 https://t.co/KnQytaXTHI

1489264699925540865.text: But Al-Qurayshi’s wrath turned to other villages throughout the region. He still captured and killed thousands and ushered in brutal violence that boosted his reputation within ISIS. After Al-Baghdadi was killed, ISIS named Al-Qurayshi their leader. 11/14 https://t.co/mNhBqJDCGW

1489264698717474818.text: We helped create a safe corridor down one side of the mountain while our aircraft targeted ISIS fighters around the perimeter. Tens of thousands of Yazidis safely got off Sinjar mountain. 10/14

1489264697253707776.text: But the threat wasn’t over, this just bought us some time. Al-Qurayshi’s forces were taking offensive positions around the mountain’s base. The Iraqi army was still in complete shambles after the fall of Mosul. The Kurds had a few forces in the area we could work with. 9/14

1489264696096088064.text: After only 36 hours of planning, three U.S. aircraft under the cover of darkness were able to drop 72 bundles of water and food within a drop zone the size of a football field along the spine of a mountain in the middle of a warzone. 8/14 https://t.co/9LFEfe3kiP

1489264694749634566.text: I sat in the Situation Room waiting for an update from the Pentagon as I worried that ISIS might try and shoot down our planes. I breathed a sigh of relief as soon as I heard that the drops were successful. 7/14

1489264693206151169.text: President Obama, facing one of the toughest decisions of his Presidency, gave us the green light that night to begin a rescue mission. We quickly exited the Oval to get the operation going. Immediately, one C-17 and two C-130s were on their way deep into ISIS-held territory. 6/14

1489264691327082504.text: They were clear: Al-Qurayshi said if the Yazidis didn’t convert to Islam they would be killed on sight with women and children taken into enslavement. Thousands of girls would be kidnapped and turned into sex slaves, raped and forced into marriage. 5/14 https://t.co/drE6qQtEU2

1489264689594843139.text: We were called into the Oval Office. We briefed the President that extermination could happen at any moment, either by starvation on top of this mountain or at the gun barrel of ISIS. This could be the single largest massacre since WWII. 4/14

1489264687392825350.text:
I paced the West Wing thinking:  is this really happening? Men, women, children fled up the mountain, abandoned their cars like some apocalyptic movie. They had no water or food after fleeing ISIS fighters who sought to exterminate them.

1478725085359972353.text: These are their words from a year ago. Let’s not let them forget. If you know of other notable statements, reply below. END

1478725084500172801.text: Senator McConnell: “Former President Trump’s actions preceding the riot were a disgraceful, disgraceful dereliction of duty. There’s no question, none, that President Trump is practically and morally responsible for provoking the events of the day.”

1478725083678093320.text: Senator Rick Scott (R) on Jan 6: “No one has a right to commit violence. What happened today at the Capitol is disgraceful and in-American. It is not what this country stands for”

1478725082788868099.text: Senator Rubio on Jan 6: “There is nothing patriotic about what is occurring on Capitol Hill. This is 3rd world style anti-American anarchy”

1478725081807437829.text: Rep Cathy Rodgers (R) on Jan 6: “What we have seen today is unlawful and unacceptable…I have decided I will vote to uphold the Electoral College results and I encourage Donald Trump to condemn and put an end to this madness.”

1478725080549052420.text: Senator Rick Scott (R) on Jan 6:  “No one has a right to commit violence. What happened today at the Capitol is disgraceful and un-American. It is not what our country stands for.”

1478725079605432329.text: Senator Cynthia Lummis (R) on Jan 6: “Call it what it is: An attack on the Capitol is an attack on democracy”

1478725078628061184.text: Senator Blackburn (R) on Jan 6: “These actions at the US Capitol by protestors are truly despicable and unacceptable. While I am safe and sheltering in place, these protests are prohibiting us from doing our constitutional duty. I condemn them in the strongest possible terms.”

1478725077684436994.text: Senator Roy Blunt (R) on Jan 6: “The events unfolding at the Capitol are shameful. There is no justification for violence and destruction. It has to stop now. This is not who we are as a nation. Thank you to the Capitol Police who are keeping us safe.”

1478725076740677638.text: Senator Barrasso (R) on Jan 6: “The violence and destruction have no place in our republic.”

1478725075830558721.text: Senator Rob Portman (R) on Jan 6: “I condemn the violent and criminal acts that took place at the US Capitol today. These shameful actions to disrupt a session of Congress and vandalize the Capitol building should never happen in our great republic”

1478725074966491146.text: Senator Ben Sasse (R) on Jan 6: “This building has been desecrated, blood has been spilled in the hallways…what happened today isn’t what America is…There are some who are trying to burn it all down, and we met some of them today.”

1478725074085720066.text: Rep Dan Crenshaw (R) on Jan 7: “On Wednesday the Capitol of the most powerful nation the world has ever known was stormed by an angry mob. Americans surely never thought they’d see such a scene…It was a display not of patriotism but of frenzy and anarchy.“

1478725073078992903.text: Senator Thune (R) on Jan 6: “I hope that the types of people who stormed the Capitol today got a clear message that they will not stop our democracy from moving forward…We need to get our work done and this kind of thuggery would not keep us from doing the people’s work”

1478725068129808391.text: Rep Chip Roy (R) on Jan 6: “Today the people’s house was attacked, which is an attack on the republic itself…People need to go to jail… and the president should never have spun up certain Americans to believe something that simply cannot be.”

1478725067215446028.text: Senator Rand Paul on Jan 6: “Chaos, anarchy. The violence today was wrong and un-American”

1478725066150055944.text:
Senator Lindsey Graham on Jan 7: 
“When it comes to accountability the president needs to understand that his actions were the problem not the solution”

1478725065105674240.text: Mike Gallagher (R) on Jan 6: “Mr. President. You have got to stop this. You are the only person who can call this off. Call it off. The election is over. Call it off. This is bigger than you. It is bigger than any member of Congress. It is about the United States of America”

1478725064271007745.text: Rep Stefanik (R) on Jan 6: “This has been a truly tragic day for America, and we all join together in fully condemning the dangerous violence and destruction…violence in any form is absolutely unacceptable, anti-American, and must be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.”

1478725063255986179.text: Rep Steve Scalise on Jan 6: “Once you start taking violent actions against law enforcement you’re not a protestor anymore, you are an anarchist. Whether it’s anarchy or terrorism, they were trying to storm the Capitol and stop our democracy from working.”

1478725062240964612.text: VP Pence on Jan 6: “Today was a dark day in the history of the United States capitol…We condemn the violence that took place here in the strongest possible terms…To those who wreaked havoc today, you did not win.”

1478725061238476800.text: Kevin McCarthy on Jan 13: “last week’s violent attack on the Capitol was undemocratic, un-American and criminal…those who are responsible for Wednesday’s chaos will be brought to justice…The President bears responsibility for Wednesday’s attack on Congress by mob rioters.”

1478725060206776320.text: Kevin McCarthy (Jan 6): The violence, destruction, and chaos we saw earlier was unacceptable undemocratic and unamerican. It was the saddest day I’ve ever had as serving as a member of this institution…We saw the worst of America this afternoon…”

1469112860433428480.text:
The interviewer went on to ask Inouye what he meant about Dole, “Do you think that suffering is unknown?”
Inouye: Not too well known, and I think it gave him strength…I admire silent sufferers. 6/8

1469112859087020035.text:
Interviewer: How do you think [Dole] should be remembered?

Inouye: As a good honest man, that he believed in his cause, but he was also a man, the way I look at him — I don’t know if others do — he silently suffered. 

https://t.co/u392VzyzEc 5/8

1469112857887490049.text: When Inouye died, Senator Dole said “I made sure to walk up to Danny’s casket. He dedicated and nearly gave his life to our nation. He deserved one more standing salute.” I was so moved that I wanted to find out how Inouye felt about Dole.  I found a moving interview. 4/8

1469112856322916352.text: Dole and Inouye kept each other company in the hospital. Inouye taught Dole how to play Bridge.  Dole shared with Inouye his aspirations for political office including Congress and both ended up serving together in the Senate for nearly 30 yrs. 3/8 https://t.co/4zQ22nFdqJ

1469112851344334853.text: Senators Dole and Inouye met each other as they recovered from their wounds in WW2 in a Michigan army hospital, a building that is now named after them. Both were seriously injured during combat in Italy. https://t.co/OiwV2JDuwH 2/8

1461086896067645440.text: PURPOSE: What does this all come down to? A boss of mine at the State Dept once told me “You don’t have good government unless you have good people working in government”. Our govt is a reflection of the people who work in it. 9/10

1461086894624759810.text: RESPECT: Democracy cannot survive without respect. When one member threatens or even suggests violence against another, this all breaks down. I voted to censure because violence in our democracy, whether at the Capitol or anywhere, seeks to silence others. 8/10

1461086892867346440.text: ACCOUNTABILITY: There are no bosses at the Capitol Building. We are accountable to our constituents, which is a good thing. We are to come together as equals charged to represent. The goal was E Pluribus Unum, “Out Of Many, One.” But achieving this goal hinges on respect. 7/10 https://t.co/C6Mf94ogtT

1461086889491013645.text:
RISE OF CONTEMPT: A huge swath of Americans view supporters of an opposing political party as the enemy. That is a very dangerous development and jeopardizes our ability to conceive of common ground. It  makes compromise and cooperation dirty words. 
https://t.co/Xs8JHeCQgZ 6/10

1461086888119447552.text: RISE OF THE OTHER: If a politician is a fighter, who or what is on the other side of the ring? Leaders can fight for constituents, a stronger economy, or better healthcare. Politicians merely fight against the other party. The negative partisanship in our country is severe. 5/10

1461086886731173894.text: RISE OF THE FIGHTER: If performance is the name of the game, what kind of show is it? Many politicians talk about themselves as fighters, I’ve done it too, but there is a dangerous line here depending on whether you define yourself as fighting “for” or “against” something. 4/10

1432490288279347203.text: MAINTAIN ATTENTION: In the coming days and weeks we will undoubtedly see a drop in media coverage on Afghanistan, but let us commit to keeping up our attention for those still in harm’s way. We still have more work to do. END

1432490286605869057.text: CARE FOR RELOCATED AFGHANS: Thousands of Afghans are now relocated to my district and communities around the US. Let us commit to caring for those that supported our military and those most vulnerable. Look here for more info: https://t.co/TEGcaQdCcD 10/11

1432490285204922368.text: PULL TOGETHER NGO/VETERAN GROUPS FOR COORDINATION: Thousands representing orgs or even just personal volunteer efforts helped identify and help Americans and Afghans. Biden admin should immediately pull all efforts together and map out and catalogs resources and contacts. 9/11

1432490283812413444.text: DEVELOP AND ENGAGE COMPLETE SIV DATABASE: A constant refrain heard over last two weeks is that we don’t know the full extent of Special Immigrant Visa applicants and eligible family members. We cannot manage such a complex process if we don’t get control over scope. 8/11

1432490282306740230.text: CONSIDER PROXY EMBASSY: We should consider ID’ing an existing embassy in Kabul to provide support to Americans in case of urgent need. In places where we don’t have physical presence, we sometimes have other nations provide basic/emergency support. Qatar or another country. 7/11

1432490280901545988.text: OPEN GROUND EXIT OPTIONS AND RESETTLEMENT: Increased diplomatic engagement needed with neighboring nations, especially Uzbekistan and Pakistan to facilitate possible land crossings. Nearly all border crossings are even more chaotic than the crowd around the airport. 6/11

1432490279408390146.text: THINK BEYOND JUST KABUL: There are possibilities for other airports in Afghanistan including Mazar-e Sharif where some were able to exit recently. 5/11

1432490277961355270.text: ACCELERATE AIRPORT FACILITATOR: Over the last week we heard chatter about having Turkey/Qatar or some other nation facilitate running of Kabul Airport. We need to expedite this urgently and need to immediately hear details from Biden admin on how and when this can happen. 4/11

1432490276556320774.text: IMMEDIATELY CONTACT CITIZENS: I know citizens left in Kabul including 4 yr old. They wanted to leave. Many were stuck at airport gates last night. They didn’t procrastinate. They, like our embassy, wanted to believe it wouldn’t all unravel so fast. They need constant contact.3/11

1432490274987651072.text: MAINTAIN TASK FORCE: State Dept must keep Afghanistan task force operational. There are major logistical challenges remaining and so many citizens/Afghans that still need help. Urge State to commit to keeping their 24/7 operation going. 2/11

1431674245940187144.text: The family had to depart the gate area that night when their phone batteries started to die. They feared being separated without means of communication. 1431674244719579138.text: I asked directly for a phone number American citizens can call if in an emergency like this family stuck at the gate. If I could get a number I planned to excuse myself from the meeting and immediately send it to the family at the gate. I was told no such number exists.5/13

1431674241716477953.text: They also feared that the Taliban checkpoints they already crossed wouldn’t stay open if they left. Within minutes of receiving this request, I happened to be meeting in person with one of the most senior officials at the State Dept. 4/13 https://t.co/g8BJmcO5Y2

1431674236335165443.text: There was a “crush of people” ahead of them. They have little kids and were concerned by the chaos surrounding them. But they didn’t want to leave because they were mere feet from reaching safety on the other side of the airport wall. 3/13 https://t.co/3FIlkQkujX

1431674231985786881.text: I was alerted earlier this week to a family trying to flee, one of over 10,000 evacuation requests sent to my office. 1431674225551724555.text: As we hit 72 hours away from Biden’s Aug 31 deadline for ending the evac mission, I’m still hearing from American Citizens, including a child, in Kabul that are terrified of being left behind. 1428815780251045894.text: US VETERANS/NATSEC COMMUNITY: I have been unbelievably moved by US veterans/servicemembers and national security officials working to help those who helped us. “I know he would do the same for me,” one said about their Afghan counterpart. Thank you all. 14/15

1428815778883772418.text: REMOVE AUG31 DEADLINE: Panic is fueled in part by deadline set before collapse. Biden said willing to stay longer if needed, but military still planning on Aug31. This is increasing panic as people feel they have only 11 days left. We should commit to stay as long as needed 13/15

1428815777256329218.text: We as a nation made a promise to these people who helped us; right now we are failing them. Biden has not yet committed to stay in Afghanistan until we get all eligible SIVs wanting to depart. We can and should make that commitment.12/15

1428815775444385795.text: SPECIAL IMMIGRANT VISA: “I worked with the soldiers on the battlefields for many years. Why do I have to wait so long? 1428815770750963717.text: WOMEN AND GIRLS: Women are afraid the Taliban will force girls to marry their soldiers. “I ask you for shelter in your country,” they pleaded. “There is no hope for girls, to live, work or study.” Several women report they cannot go outside for basic needs and groceries. 10/15 https://t.co/SOQhgcLe45

1428815766850310144.text: OUTSIDE OF KABUL: While the bulk of media/attention is focused on Kabul, many Afghans live across the country and cannot dream of getting to Kabul right now. 1428815763264135174.text: We should use every available means to get people to safety, public and private alike. The U.S. cannot be an impediment. 1428815761792016387.text: COMMERCIAL/CHARTER FLIGHTS: Yesterday I spent hours talking to people who had lined up chartered flights to evac people from Kabul, but were being told by the U.S. that commercial/charters flights were not allowed to land or depart even if they weren’t heading to the U.S. 7/15

1428815760231649285.text: Other NATO countries are reportedly conducting pick ups around Kabul and transporting people to the airport. If in fact the Taliban agreed to allow Americans to travel safely to the airport as Biden stated, the administration should take up this effort to transport. 6/15

1428815757501214721.text: FEAR GETTING TO AIRPORT: While supposedly Americans are allowed through the multiple Taliban checkpoints set up through Kabul, many are rightfully still concerned. 1428815748621811715.text: Some people we are helping got email from US gov to head to the airport, but after making the journey, they get stuck at the gate. It is inexcusable that we cannot find a way to get those approved into the airport. We need a direct POC to call once people are at the gate 4/15

1428815746772213764.text: AIRPORT GATE: The top problem we hear is chaos at airport gate. One said, “Injuries due to the use of tear gas...children separated from the adults and trampled by the crowd.” A US perm resident has been stuck 3 days without getting in, “This is the most inhumane process.” 3/15 https://t.co/IorS3paxN8

1428815742510772226.text: “I’M BEING HUNTED”: Multiple credible reports of the Taliban going door to door. 1427637579814514689.text: If we question our efforts, we should just look again at that photo of the packed C-17 and put ourselves in the shoes of the 600+ willing to risk everything for freedom. This is what America is about — the pursuit of freedom. END

1427637578375868417.text: We have a choice as a nation right now. I hope we make the right one and maintain control over Kabul airport long enough to evacuate all that we can help. I fear for those left on tarmac when the final US plane departs. 10/11

1427637573997015052.text: The P-2 visa that America set up requires Afghans to travel to a third country to be processed. This is beyond impossible for those reaching out to me from outside Kabul airport. We should include P-2 eligible people in our evacuations and process their visas elsewhere. 7/11

1427637572524728327.text: I’m glad we are evacuating local staff from our embassy and their spouses and kids. But I hear the cries of families worried about whether they have to leave behind grandparents and others. Families are confronting that not everyone can make it. We can and must do better. 6/11

1427637571186839555.text: We cannot let bureaucracy get in the way of saving lives. The people I talk to in Afghanistan do not have access to the internet to fill forms, many don’t have any documentation as they fled too quickly. We can sort out details in a safer environment. 5/11

1427637569609682960.text: I was taught to not kick the ladder out from under us. We have to commit as a nation to take in refugees. I know some disagree, and I ask that you reconsider after seeing these horrid scenes from Afghanistan. 4/11

1427637568234049545.text: Many of your families, like my parents, came to America with no money and no support network. My parents still remember the Americans who gave them a hand, helped them in their time of need. Now we must pay it forward. 3/11

1427637566757552141.text: We are a nation that honors their grit. That same grit that gives these Afghans the courage to do what they are doing is the grit that strengthens America. Many of our parents, grandparents, and others came to America with that same grit after wars, disasters, and hardship. 2/11

1427637564857626627.text: This photo of 600+ Afghans squeezed into a C-17 is so powerful; take a moment to put yourself in their shoes. No luggage. May never see their home country again. 1427056153448566786.text: But let’s at least unite and commit as a nation to save as many people as we can. Right now. No excuses. Let’s do everything we can. Put aside partisanship and help those who helped us. END

1427056152131612675.text: I worked in Afghanistan 10 years ago. It was clear that the Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) didn’t have deep roots. I saw that again when I visited in 2019 on a bipartisan Congressional delegation. A failure by both parties over the years. 10/11

1427056150969716741.text: To take a step back, this is all very hard to accept. Part of me wanted to believe that Afghanistan would hold. But someone just reminded me, “No one wants this to be real.” We don’t want to accept that this crisis is happening, but we must. 9/11

1427056149594087426.text: While we are helping with flights out, we must try to guarantee safe passage to the airport. There are also people who worked in the Afghan gov/security forces/civil society that will likely be targeted for reprisal. Humanitarian parole or something else must occur. 8/11

1427056148260265994.text: We are getting people on planes, and I know the State Dept is prioritizing local staff, spouses, and their kids. That is the right thing to do. It’s another story to get them to the airport. I heard some say “we have Talibs in Kabul.” Something we never wanted to hear. 7/11

1427056146926514179.text: If money and resources are needed, I will work tooth and nail to urgently provide. Otherwise, it’s just bureaucracy, and that cannot be an excuse for inaction. We cannot respond to these urgent pleas I and others are receiving and just say we can’t move that fast. 6/11

1427056145731133440.text: We should also help them because how will anyone in dangerous areas choose to work with America if we don’t fulfill our promises to help those that help us. It is unprecedented to evacuate at this speed, but the times call upon us to do so. That is the American handshake. 5/11

1427056144527282176.text: I cannot name them for fear of reprisal but their pleas for help are heartbreaking. I worked there 10 years ago, and I know first hand how much these Afghans risked their lives and their families to work with us. We should help them because it is the right thing to do. 4/11

1427056143306788865.text: Thousands of Afghans who worked alongside Americans for the last 20 years are at great risk.  We can help them. We can set aside the bureaucracy that has backlogged their visa applications for years and just get them out of danger. We have to prioritize them. 3/11

1427056141968809986.text: The immediate question on many of our minds is how did we get here? I have many thoughts on that, but first let’s focus on saving as many lives as possible in the next few days and weeks. Let’s remember that those most in harm’s way are Afghans fighting for their lives. 2/11

1427056140546973698.text: I continue to struggle finding the words to describe the tragedy in Afghanistan. I’ve spent most of the last few days trying to get Afghans that I know out of the country. Their pleas are raw and cannot be ignored. I know full well that some might not make it. (THREAD)

1412399095394750471.text: Patriotism isn’t to think we are infallible; it is to know we make mistakes but to love our nation and one another with care enough to fix the injustices that remain. To know our resilience. To have humility to know that we are a part of something bigger than all of us. 16/17

1412399094446931973.text: Smithsonian is entrusted to help tell the story of America. It isn’t always a pretty story, but it is an unfinished story with the persistent hope that it will improve and that we can repair our faults. More importantly, it is our story. It is shared truth binding us as one.15/17

1412399093498908677.text: Instead of trying to erase history they don’t like after the fact, politicians should just act in a way that doesn’t produce such shameful results. It’s not hard to not incite or cover up an insurrection. 14/17

1412399092257411076.text: There are those trying to erase what happened, voting against commissions/committees aimed at documenting history. They say just move on and turn the page. But I say, you can’t turn the page of American history until you write the page first. 13/17 https://t.co/HeoCM9WkZ4

1412399089577234439.text: I told the Smithsonian yes to donating the blue suit because the telling of the story of Jan6 isn’t optional, it is necessary. There are many stories of Jan6. 1412399086570033153.text: The story of that day wasn’t just destruction. There was hope and resilience. The Capitol Police were heroes that saved lives. Colleagues and staff showed bravery. 1412399083642404866.text: When the Smithsonian requested the suit, I tried to imagine what an exhibit about Jan6 would look like. Perhaps it would have broken glass from shattered doors, torn flags and signs. Video of the mob trying to hijack our democracy. But there was so much more to that day. 10/17 https://t.co/3ocvv7Xe82

1412399080634994696.text: The Smithsonian called later in January. Honestly, I wasn’t thinking about how the day would be remembered as I was still living it. In fact, after the call, I had to pull over on the side of I-95 as I started to tear up uncontrollably while driving home. I was still not ok.9/17

1412399079208984579.text: People wrote saying the blue suit gave them a sense of resilience and hope. For me, I was in a tough place. In days after Jan6 I had an unshakable regret that I didn’t do more to keep people safe. But feeling of hope/resilience in the cards helped me feel stronger. Thank you.8/17 https://t.co/OMUix6TKIU

1412399075895414785.text: In the following days, I started to receive thousands of cards from across the country. Many from kids. Strangers who wanted to tell me how they felt when they saw the photo of me. They talked about the blue suit. The suit meant something different to them than it did to me.7/17 https://t.co/5BCe6VJaH7

1412399072254758914.text: When I got home I vowed to never wear the suit again. I even considered throwing it away. It only brought back terrible memories. I could never separate that suit from the events of Jan6. I hid it in my closet as I never wanted to see it again. But then something happened. 6/17 https://t.co/pSf2duFRsK

1412399069197123585.text: JANUARY 13: The last time I wore the blue suit wasn’t Jan 6, it was Jan13. I wore it when I walked onto the House floor to cast my vote for impeachment. 1406603646998024197.text: Graduation is a tradition meant to distinguish moments in our lives from others. We think of life in stages that we progress through. 1406603646092066819.text: During his first Christmas performance he cried and ran offstage. Not this time. He showed me that he sees a bright world of possibilities. 1406603645223849986.text: During the graduation, there was a sweet part where the kids took turns talking about their dream jobs. 1406603644334657536.text: I feel deep uncertainty about the world my son is growing up in. Our struggling democracy, climatechange, hate against AsianAmericans or anyone for that matter. 1399771508768186368.text: REFLECTION: We’ve undoubtedly made progress over the past century, but the fuel for that hatred and violence hasn’t completely gone away. 1399771507069497344.text: COST: Hundreds were killed and millions in generational wealth was lost. Just as impactful is the psychological cost. We can only imagine the horror for Black Americans across the country to see a thriving community destroyed with no cause but their race. 6/14

1399771505706377222.text: TERROR: That hate wasn’t just a handful of misguided men. Some were deputized by authorities and given weapons. This wasn’t just done out of retribution, it was done to completely silence a community. 5/14

1399771504393568264.text: SPARK: A comprehensive report from 2001 explains that a false assault allegation against a Black teen was the catalyst for violence. But that spark only ignited something that went deeper: an idea that Black power and prosperity was zero-sum and needed to end. 4/14

1399771503021993993.text: SEPARATED: Business owners and working families prospered even though they were segregated from the rest of the community. Every day was a reminder that they were an ‘other’ - even those well-off in Greenwood couldn’t frequent businesses in White Tulsa. 3/14

1399771501184827392.text: PROSPERITY: The Greenwood area of Tulsa was a thriving Black community and often referred to as Black Wall Street. The residents succeeded against the odds, but their success was a model and a symbol for what could be. 2/14 https://t.co/PQdlkYapK4

1399771496957026309.text: 100 years ago today, a thriving Black community in Tulsa was destroyed by a white mob driven by hate and anger. 1380888371531280385.text: How do we fight against the rising authoritarianism and stop the erosion of our democracy here at home? The counterweight to authoritarianism is engraved in the very ceiling of the Oval Office. 10/14

1380888369912279042.text: In this era of growing authoritarianism around the globe it’s more important than ever that we protect and reinforce the institutions of our democracy. After insurrection, we know we are not immune to this threat and Georgia voter suppression law shows attacks continue. 9/14 https://t.co/UKwcTShD43

1380888367018209281.text: The White House is more than a symbol. It is the physical manifestation of Article 2 of Constitution with its power derived from the American people. The building is bigger than any of us, bigger than our political parties, bigger than any President who occupies it. 8/14

1380888365457936393.text: I was heartbroken when I saw the White House disrespected and used as a political prop. I took part in 3 events on South Lawn. Sept 11 memorial, July4 celebration and arrival ceremony for Head of State visit. That is sacred ground. Campaigning has no place at White House. 7/14 https://t.co/5YbmuECJ3K

1380888362727444483.text: I carried forward that sense of awe and respect, even through small gestures. I kept a pair of pristine black shoes under my desk that I would only wear when called into Oval Office. I wanted to treat that room differently. The White House demands and deserves our respect. 6/14

1380888361217490950.text: BIGGER THAN US: During that first visit as a child, my mom bought me this medallion marking 200 yrs of Presidency. As a 7 yr old, that seemed like an impossibly big number. I tied this to my bedpost growing up. I proudly hung it by my desk when I worked there 24 yrs later. 5/14 https://t.co/QiQcBmmSna

1380888357664874499.text: That sense of participation stuck with me years later when I started work at the White House. The first time I ever stepped foot in OvalOffice I was so nervous, but I remembered I was invited. I had something to contribute. As an American, this building belongs to all of us. 4/14 https://t.co/U0mtdgRTza

1380888353181159429.text: PEOPLE’S HOUSE: I remember how proud my mom was that as an immigrant she was able to walk us into the White House. We wandered the Rose Garden. I felt connected to my government. I wasn’t intimidated, I was invited. I wasn’t excluded, instead I felt welcomed to participate. 3/14 https://t.co/ureKfeCTpb

1380888345761476615.text: That was the last time I was in the White House. The first time I entered that sacred building was when my mother took me as a boy. She taught me two things: 1) This house belongs to the people and 2) this building (and our democracy) is bigger than any of us. 2/14 https://t.co/arQicrW9HB

1380888339302248452.text: 5 years ago this week, I walked my family into the Oval Office. I watched my immigrant mom speechless as she shook hands with Pres Obama while he held my 6 m/o baby boy. Three generations of my family in the Oval with the President. I kept thinking “This is America”(THREAD) https://t.co/Vge7pS2Qpo

1378355215687151616.text: DEDICATION: Hyun Jung Grant was single mom survived by two boys who said she “dedicated her whole life to providing” and was the “strongest influence on who we are today.” They buried her where she can “rest basking in a constant warmth of daylight.”8/11 https://t.co/hlkSVFusf8

1378355206933598210.text: CARE: My mom told me about racist patients at the hospital who would yell hurtful words at her like “Go back to where you’re from!” Despite their hate, she would care for them. Bathe them, feed them, give them medicine, watch over them as they recovered. 4/11

1378355205612433416.text: ENDURANCE:Their powerful reflections hit me hard. When I was young, my mom worked night shift as hospital nurse so she could take care of sister and me during daytime. I asked her once when she had time to sleep. She said simply, “I don’t know.” Moms have superhuman strength.3/11

1376960802679357445.text: BUILD COMMUNITY: I shared last week that I believe the opposite of feeling foreign is to be loved in a community. My mom told me comforting words: “You are never alone. 1376960798334070791.text: YOU BELONG/WE BELONG: The words violently hurled at this woman “You don’t belong here” are intentionally meant to draw distance and isolate. 1376960794647277571.text: Responding to the pain of others isn’t about charity, it is about responsibility. We have responsibility to those around us, as they do for us. We treat others as we want to be treated. We help others as we hope to be helped in our moments of need. 8/11

1376960793498021888.text: IT IS OUR RESPONSIBILITY: The lack of action during the attack and then shutting the door after threat is over speaks less to fear and more to callousness. Closing the door delineates that this is not my world and therefore I don’t need to act. I don’t have responsibility.7/11

1376960792378105868.text: IT IS OUR BUSINESS: If we see someone else hurt, it's still our business. Even if doorman didn’t intervene in attack for fear of personal harm, he and others should have checked on woman afterwards. Action is not binary. It doesn’t have to be superhero or nothing. 6/11

1376960791241449476.text: It is difficult to talk about bystanders because it’s hard to cast judgment when we weren’t there. Would I have stepped in? I don't know for sure. Instead of coming from a place of hypotheticals/moral superiority, I’m considering principles to recommit to. 5/11

1376960790146736134.text: As we grow more siloed, we start to see one another as the “other.” Without sharedness we lose touch with responsibility. What are our responsibilities when we are neither perpetrator nor direct victim? What about when we witness hate or suffering of others with our own eyes 4/11

1376960789089771523.text: I feel like this is so metaphorical to the challenges we face as a nation right now. We as a society are having a crisis of empathy. What we are losing is that important sense of sharedness. Whether that is shared experiences, shared truths, shared space, shared identity. 3/11

1376960787504369666.text: When that door closes, it sends a clear message. It says I’m not going to help. It says this is none of my business. It says to the woman, you don’t belong in this building; keep your problems outside. It says this is not my responsibility. 2/11 https://t.co/sEDnHx3wAo

1375815791606644737.text: I reassured my mom that she raised me well and with strength to face down discrimination. She and I then talked about what we think the boys are taking away from growing up during this moment of immense chaos in our nation where racism is so out in the open? 9/13

1375815790088306689.text: My mom said she would tell me about racism I may face and then follow up with “You are very special. Keep being yourself. You are never alone. 1375815786749644807.text: I told @Capehartj my parents never talked to me when I was a child about discrimination I might face. I called my mom yesterday to seek her thoughts. She told me she wished she had the words then to prepare me. I asked my mom what she would want to tell me as a kid. 7/13

1375815785583677442.text: I would want them to hear some of the hurtful words that they may hear from me and their mom first, hoping that might take out some of the bite. I would want to tell them some of the struggles that I faced so they know it happens to others. But what else should I say? 6/13

1375815784090468355.text:

1373282049797324804.text: Pres Biden and VP Harris went to Atlanta yesterday to shine a light on the rise in AAPI hate. Now they have an opportunity to make sure the 20 positions at DoJ are reflective of the country they keep safe. More than 100 open positions at StateDept. 10/13 https://t.co/RYedNWjpTd

1373282046269927425.text: And now in the aftermath of the brutal mass murder in ATL, we as a nation must confront the xenophobia, discrimination that AAPIs experience. I wanted to show as we turn to Gov right now to fix these problems, that Gov itself has problems we must fix. 9/13

1373282044806053893.text: StateDept and our government as a whole needs to confront the lack of diversity in its ranks. We need a government that looks a lot more like the rest of America. And State is meant to be a place where we show rest of the world our diversity. 8/13

1373282043644280837.text: I started to feel like maybe I didn’t have a place in government. I started to think about quitting.  Everyone keeps saying our diversity is our strength. That letter from StateDept said otherwise. How do I do foreign policy if my own government treats me like I’m foreign? 7/13

1373282042155270145.text: I raised my concerns about this letter to more senior people at State and was advised by several to not make a fuss about it since I wasn’t actually interested in working on Korea. They missed the point. I wasn’t thinking of my career path, I was thinking of respect. 6/13

1373282041039585284.text: I understand security concerns all over the world. I understand that I share a last name with a brutal dictator. That’s why I endured grueling clearance processes multiple times. But once I received a Top Secret clearance, why this letter? 5/13

1373282039609311238.text: I thought to myself how I was born here in America. I don’t even speak Korean well at all. I have relatives in South Korea but I barely know them. I kept asking Why did my government not trust me? 4/13

1373282038355259394.text: And it wasn’t just me. I learned that other Asian Americans at State had same thing happen. It was called “assignment restrictions” - a bureaucratic way of saying “failing loyalty test.”   https://t.co/Ip7w8wy6C0 3/13

1373282037122097153.text: I had previously worked in Afghanistan for State. I had a top secret security clearance. But here was a letter saying we don’t trust you. What confused me more is that I didn’t even apply to work on Korea. The StateDept was proactively telling me they didn’t trust me. 2/13

1373282035633119233.text: I’ll never forget the feeling when I learned that my own government questioned my loyalty. Before Congress I worked in diplomacy at StateDept. 1367173213889974276.text: We cannot serve the people properly if we do not treat them with respect. Or to say it another way, no one should be disrespected. Not Anna, not anyone. 14/14

1367173213059502085.text: Public service demands the best of us. We should be held to high standards. We should have the capacity for respect for each and every person we meet, no matter how brief. Our job is to literally serve the people. 13/14

1367173212287741954.text: Respect should be the starting point, not the finish line, and harm should never be done. 12/14

1367173211423711236.text: How do we serve people if we don’t treat them with dignity and respect? This goes beyond just public officials too. Our concern is not just about how people treat strangers. Must also be about our colleagues/staff, our family/friends, our competitors, our acquaintances. 11/14

1367173210521878533.text: I heard in my friend’s voice what happens when we encounter people who disrespect us, sometimes crossing lines without knowing or caring. As elected officials, we hold positions of perceived power and have solemn responsibility to examine our actions through that structure. 10/14

1367173209691467778.text: I can never fully understand what Anna and others experienced, but from their truth I hope it forces people in power - and everyone else - to ask these difficult questions and look at their own actions with increased scrutiny. 9/14

1367173208839962644.text: Years later now as a public official myself, I carry so many of those 30 second moments with me when I meet people. I ask myself: am I giving this person my respect? Am I treating this person as I’d want to be treated? 8/14

1367173207950831616.text: Anna and I worked at White House several years ago. Young staffers surrounded by powerful people. It was intimidating. I don’t know Anna’s experience, but in my career, I saw a huge range of how people respected and disrespected others, especially women and people of color. 7/14

1367173207036411912.text: I thought all night about that line she said. When we meet people, especially strangers, how do we want to spend that time together? But it also fundamentally gets at the question of respect. Do we respect the people we meet? Do our actions reflect respect? 6/14

1367173206176579590.text: She paused in her description and asked if that is how he wanted to spend the 30 seconds with her, a complete stranger, what does that say about him? She paused again and reframed the sentence, “that is how he chose to spend the 30 seconds meeting me.” 5/14

1367173205216137216.text: Something she said to me stood out. She remarked how the encounter with Governor Cuomo was brief but was seared into her memory with a deep vividness. I could tell it still made her uncomfortable to think about it as that strong, confident tone began to soften. 4/14

1367173204146552838.text: It was hearing from other women of their experiences of sexual harassment, assault, and abuse that got her to stand up and speak out. Anna did not compare her experience to those of others, but instead said she wanted to let others know that she is with them in solidarity. 3/14

1367173203286765568.text: Anna sounded strong. She always has been for the years I’ve known her and her voice was confident. We talked about why she decided to share her story. She was honest about how she struggled with the decision. Ultimately, she felt compelled to say something. 2/14

1365712306781507586.text: If we make exceptions to upholding those values out of convenience or fear, they’ll mean nothing. I hope that we will not only respond to the magnitude of the acts confirmed in this memo, I hope we raise the standard so that these acts are never repeated. 14/15

1365712305917411330.text: The world is facing a critical moment of monumental change. We’ve seen the rise of strongmen and the fall of basic freedoms. MBS targeting Khashoggi, Putin targeting Navalny, Duterte targeting thousands of his own citizens are all abhorrent acts. 13/15

1365712305099530241.text: When we make exceptions for our allies in situations like this, we project to the rest of the world that our values only go as far as our relationships. We show countries like Russia and China that we may have convictions, but consequences are never guaranteed. 12/15

1365712304168460293.text: Yes, sanctions were announced, and that is an important step in the right direction, but the lack of action against the Crown Prince sends a clear message across the globe that those at the top can escape consequences. 11/15

1365712303346380805.text: Why is it always on us to take steps to preserve the relationship?  Why isn’t it on the Crown Prince or others that have betrayed values? His decision to murder a resident of America set this in motion. Should be on him if they want to repair. 10/15

1365712302499110914.text: Why did the Crown Prince think he could get away with this? Because he didn’t expect us to act on accountability. That is a sign of a deeply unhealthy alliance. Now some are saying we need to back down to preserve the relationship because too many interests are at stake. 9/15

1365712301236641793.text: WHAT KIND OF KING MIGHT HE BE: This is how a 35 year old in line to be King acts. It presages what we would potentially expect for decades to come. If we accept this behavior now, what does that mean for the next half century? 8/15 https://t.co/B6SV5EpIdi

1365712298325798912.text: ABSOLUTE CONTROL: In this memo, those two words stood out to me. Crown Prince had absolute control over security and intel operations. Supported violent measures to silence dissidents. Aides were unlikely to question orders for fear of firing or being arrested. 7/15

1365712297470160901.text: Criticism/penalty are not just for enemies. If America is truly going to be seen as a leader in the world, we need to hold allies accountable. In this case accountability means taking actions against the Crown Prince. Otherwise we need to reassess what it means to be an ally 6/15

1365712296618713090.text: I’ve worked on Middle East diplomacy for years and that work sometimes put me in the same room with people that undoubtedly had blood on their hands. I learned that a willingness to work alongside a country should never translate into a blank check to violate our values. 5/15

1365712295356203010.text: WHAT’S MISSING?: Memo leaves out how Khashoggi died. Strangled dismembered with a bone saw, potentially while still alive. Audio of death supposedly shared with CIA and likely listened to by NIO who authored this memo. Killer says “I know how to cut.” None of that in memo. 4/15 https://t.co/47Dw4ffb82

1365712292306964482.text: WHO WROTE THIS? The summary says questions to be directed to the NIO for Near East. This is important. NIO stands for National Intelligence Officer who sits on the National Intelligence Committee at the CIA and is the most senior analyst on the Middle East in our government. 3/15

1365712290427916289.text: HIGH CONFIDENCE: The memo starts with “We assess that…” While that doesn’t seem like a blistering opening, for me, it’s like a hammer. Lack of phrases like “low/medium confidence” is striking and rare. Unusual to have such a clear and definite assessment without modifier. 2/15 https://t.co/u982Vvn11S

1365712287336660998.text: I just finished reading the declassified memo on killing of #Khashoggi. I’ve read thousands of intel reports in my career in national security, but this one stands out.
