1362806088798785536.text: Violence against AAPI isn’t just an AAPI problem. But also anti-AAPI descrimination is not the only discrimination that AAPIs should care about. Hate/racism in all forms is despicable. I don’t claim to fully understand the deep racism others face but we lift each other up. 17/19

1362806087980904453.text: We need the development of thicker and more sustained grassroots engagement that so often feels lacking in AAPI political outreach. And we need to ensure that this effort has a wide coalition beyond just the AAPI community. 16/19

1362806087032840195.text: We need voices at all levels of gov speaking out. Need Governors to come up with their own state-level plans and to meaningfully reach out to AAPI communities in their states. We need a punchlist of what local municipalities and law enforcement need to take this seriously. 15/19

1362806086072426498.text: Congress should pass the NO HATE ACT to put more resources to tackling hate crimes in our nation (the House passed it in May 2020). We should hold hearings to shine light on this violence as well as other discriminatory concerns and give AAPI community a greater voice. 14/19

1362806085153923074.text: We need Biden team to prioritize re-establishing White House Initiative on AAPI to create a designated portal for sustained engagement and relationship building with AAPI communities around the country. 13/19

1362806084340219907.text: So what do we do? We need the Biden admin to designate a point person on hate crimes and to direct DoJ and FBI to allocate more resources including creation of single reporting channel to flag discriminatory actions, hate crimes training, and real AAPI community outreach. 12/19

1362806083492921350.text: PROVING WORTH: When I’m asked about why gov should engage with AAPI, I’m often hit with stats about fastest growing demographic and margin of victory in GA runoffs. All true. But we shouldn’t have to justify worth. We are worth protecting not just because of usefulness. 11/19

1362806082008207365.text: REMOVAL: What I experienced is but a mere speck compared to the scars of Japanese Americans rounded up in internment camps. Today is the Remembrance Day for that stain on our history. Our government did this. We must remember. 10/19 https://t.co/Lxb5udo1MC

1362806079034449924.text: This letter was completely unprompted. I can tell you exactly how it feels to have your own government say “we don’t trust you,” even after I worked in warzones on behalf of our nation. It hurt, still does. 9/19

1362806078195564551.text: LOYALTY TEST: I worked for years as a diplomat at the State Dept. Top Secret clearance working on the wars in Iraq/Afghanistan. But State Dept one day sent me a letter saying I could not work on any issues related to Korea. I was confused because I never requested to do so. 8/19

1362806076211625987.text: OTHERIZATION: When I ran for Congress in 2018, a TV ad ended with the line “Andy Kim, he’s not one of us.” They tried to say I’m foreign, I’m not American no matter what, that I’m an “other.” Sadly not the first time I experienced this type of attack questioning my loyalty. 7/19 https://t.co/3YYLoJRA66

1362806072440979456.text: COWARDICE: Attacking our elders is also the most cowardly way to show hate. Violence against frailty is despicable and demonstrates a particular insecurity. Sadly it also demonstrates an absence of decency that has been filled by anger.  6/19

1362806071396626438.text: CUT DEEP: Our elders are our roots. They are often the ones who had the infinite courage to journey to America and build a new life in pursuit of the American dream. Attacking them makes us feel like we are weeds being pulled up by our roots. This is no doubt intentional. 5/19

1362806070482259976.text: DISRESPECT: When I yelled at my grandma, I disrespected her. I disrespected my family’s history. I disrespect what others did to give me what I have. When people attack AAPIs, they disrespect our shared history and our place. 4/19

1362806069618221057.text: Yes, some is covid-related discrimination inflamed by the former president, but that is not the whole story though it is what the media often latches onto. The history of anti-AAPI sentiment is long but often unseen or forgotten, representing several principles of hate. 3/19

1361012215109873664.text: Mandela, in his speech, said, “Our march to freedom is irreversible. We must not allow fear to stand in our way.” We can’t and we won’t. Not as long as we all pledge to seize this moment and work towards justice. 12/13

1361012213574754304.text: Accountability and justice for the insurrection on January 6th failed in the Senate, but just because 43 Senators failed to use their vote to protect our democracy doesn’t mean you can’t. 11/13

1361012212412928002.text: I know there’s a lot of frustration after yesterday’s vote in the Senate, but Mandela’s story shows us hope. He told us to “seize this moment so that the process towards democracy is rapid and uninterrupted.” Democracy may have taken a hit, but his words ring true today. 10/13

1361012211435634688.text:
VISION: “I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities.”

Mandela ended with a positive vision to show that what they were fighting for was bigger than him, bigger than all. 9/13

1361012210429030404.text:
COURAGE: “Our march to freedom is irreversible.  We must not allow fear to stand in our way.”  

It must have been powerful to stand in that crowd in Cape Town and hear a man who was imprisoned for 27 years to say we cannot subject ourselves to fear. 8/13

1361012209464311812.text:
ORGANIZATION: “It is only through disciplined mass action that our victory can be assured.”  

The vision for change that Mandela presented wasn’t one of elites in power. Change would happen “only” through mass action. He also noted that these actions must be “disciplined.” 7/13

1361012208415694848.text:
AGENCY:  “We call on our people to seize this moment so that the process towards democracy is rapid and uninterrupted.”  
 
He underscored the urgency of now and showed who was empowered to make this decision. It would be “our people” who would seize this moment. 6/13

1361012207316852741.text:
URGENCY: “Our struggle has reached a decisive moment.”

Mandela used the speech to set the tone for the work ahead. His release was not the climax, but instead just the possibility of change. No assumptions could be made of what comes next. 5/13

1361012205777543171.text:
SOLIDARITY: “I salute the working class...religious communities..the endless heroism of youth.. the mothers and wives and sisters of our nation”

He focused on the contributions of the many and showed respect to those often overlooked. He showed the vitalness of coalitions. 4/13 https://t.co/TfXrMTXota

1361012198978555905.text:
HUMILITY: “I stand before you not as a prophet but as a humble servant of you, the people.” 

Mandela was revered by millions as a leader of conscience. But in his second sentence, he made sure to set the tone for humility and service. No individuals stand above the people. 3/13 https://t.co/tgENBEfkPs

1361012192871669760.text:
GRACE:  “I greet you all in the name of peace, democracy and freedom for all.”

Robbed of 27 years of his life, no one would have faulted Mandela if he emerged from prison with anger. But instead, with his first words of his first speech in decades, he chose grace. 2/13 https://t.co/Dw0Ew88fHB

1361012187062534150.text: At my office in Congress I have an original ballot of Mandela’s election as reminder to never take democracy for granted. 1359607594428600320.text: We should do all these things. We should do them now. And we should make sure our Postal Service is always seen as the Service it truly is.

1359607593652654092.text: There are things that Congress can and should do right now too. Things that have actual bipartisan support like ending the pre-paying of benefits which harm’s the USPS financially.

1359607592776048645.text: We have a new administration now and one that understands the importance of the USPS and its role as a service to our nation. There are vacant positions on the board of governors they can and should fill immediately.

1359607591731662856.text: But as you hopefully read in this article, that wasn’t the aim of the Trump Administration. They, and their appointees didn’t see this as a Service. That’s a big reason why your packages are late and mail is delayed.

1359607590733422593.text: And beyond being a service, the USPS is an incredible path to the middle class for so many. It’s our largest employer of veterans and provides good union jobs. We should aim to protect that!

1359607589865218052.text: For every person that says, “well surely one of the private companies can do that”, the answer is that the Postal Service brings a lot of packages the last mile. They do it because they have to; because they’re a service.

1359607588988608513.text: For every quip about “who sends a letter anymore?” - the answer is a lot of people! Sure, more people are communicating from their phone, but every package sent from a small or large business needs to be sent, and the USPS is there to do it.

1359607588107784194.text: The Postal Service is exactly that: a service. It’s not here to make a profit, it’s here to connect people. That’s the vision our founders had. It’s a vision that is still so relevant to this day.

1359607586161635330.text: One of the things I hear most about through my Congressional office is issues people continue to have with the USPS. I hope you take a moment to read @EllieRushing’s piece, but wanted to add a few more thoughts. https://t.co/y4Tl8VzXba

1358908990671962113.text: This is a long road, and it’s going to take work. But this country is worth it - we are worth it - and I’ll be working every step of the way.

1358908989199835138.text: We also need to invest in civics and citizenship. Not a phony patriotism, but a true understanding of the roles and responsibilities we have as Americans to our country and to each other.

1358908987735949316.text: Accountability without reform just sets us up to hold more people accountable in the future. We need to make our political system more responsive to the people it serves and bring it closer to them to make it truly relevant to their lives.

1358908986309939207.text: But holding those responsible accountable doesn’t fix the problems we face. It’s only a part of the solution set we need to pursue as a country.

1358908984682496000.text: We’re going to talk a lot about accountability in the next week. Impeachment is a key component to that effort. As is arresting those who participated in the attack of the Capitol itself.

1358906925472223235.text: Earlier today I joined @ChrisJansing on @MSNBC to talk about last month’s attack on the Capitol. She asked a great question about accountability and I wanted to share my thoughts with you. https://t.co/DzQJbx3nth

1358459986377072646.text: Healing as a nation starts with acknowledging the trauma of the events on January 6th. Thanks to @TheSundayShow for having me on with @LisaBRochester and @benraylujan to tell our stories and move the healing process forward. https://t.co/YfrRS6hfx3

1358137219832307722.text: And finally, we need to recognize that this is the job of all of us - not just those at the Capitol. We are part of a singular American story. I am working on some ideas to do just this and I hope to work with all of you. I hope that is the true legacy of Jan 6. (end)

1358137095194345474.text: We need to rebuild trust, understanding and accountability for our democratic institutions. We need to invest in civics and service to counteract lies and hate.

1358136868169265153.text: We must also work to strengthen the very institutions placed under attack. Our democracy is far too fragile if a demagog with a social media account and a megaphone can incite an insurrection.

1358136732676485124.text: The actions of those who perpetrated this attack - from inciting it to the death of a police officer - must be punished as to send a clear signal that violence is not an acceptable path to political change.

1358133728413949953.text: We must also work to strengthen the very institutions placed under attack. Our democracy is far too fragile if a demagog with a social media account and a megaphone can incite an insurrection.

1358133548771921921.text: The actions of those who perpetrated this attack - from inciting it to the death of a police officer - must be punished as to send a clear signal that violence is not an acceptable path to political change.

1358133406886989829.text: We cannot, for a moment, treat the attack of 1/6 as something normal that happened. It was a truly dark day in our nation's history and it deserves a response of that magnitude.

1358133244366114821.text: What we do next with that resolve is on my mind today. Do we let this moment fade, let those who brought our country to the brink of disaster be held unaccountable, or let the conditions that led to this attack go unaddressed? No.

1358132865838505984.text: SYMBOL OF HOPE: When I arrived at my office this week, there were hundreds of cards from all over the country expressing hope from the image of me cleaning the rotunda. 1350891371645833225.text: Let’s honor those individuals that we lost while we fight against the fatigue we might feel. We can still save thousands of lives if we work together. Be safe, everyone.

1350891180624646144.text: This week when you reflect on the tragic milestone of 400k deaths, don’t think of the number; think of a person or a family you know who was affected by the virus.

1350891052346073088.text: Our job as regular Americans is not to save hundreds of thousands of lives but to protect ourselves and those around us. Through collective action we can conjure what is necessary to make monumental change.

1350890915183927296.text: The monumental number makes it harder for us to think individuals play a role in solving the problem. I used to feel like the only way to solve a massive problem is through an equally massive solution. But this minimizes the role we have in wearing a mask and social distancing.

1350890713744093185.text: Yes we want to honor those that we lost and recognize the scope of the suffering. But from my experience, these staggering numbers often pull us further away from the humanity of the crisis and can make us more numb to the loss. We cannot visualize how large of a number 400k is.

1350890576053469186.text: In the next 24 hours we will hit 400k COVID deaths. Two days later we will surpass the total deaths of Americans during WW2. I previously worked to stop genocide/mass atrocity and my advice to you is to not get fixated on the numbers but instead focus on something personal.

1304397521930903552.text: After the tragic attacks on September 11th, many made the ultimate sacrifice in an effort to achieve peace and security. May we honor their memories today and everyday by working together to move this country forward.

1304397521003966464.text: Although our political climate may feel more divided than ever, I hope we can continue to find common ground as we did in the days after the attacks 19 years ago.

1304397520123166720.text: First responders saved lives, leaders secured funding to rebuild communities, and soldiers signed up to serve abroad to defend our nation. No one cared if you were a Democrat or a Republican, we banded together as Americans.

1304397519066193920.text: That tragic day forever changed our state, our country, and the world. It has had an immense impact on my own life and the lives of far too many in our community. One of the things that has stuck with me the most is how, in the immediate aftermath, we came together to heal.

1304397518093066240.text: It's been 19 years since the September 11th attacks shocked the world and devastated our nation. Nearly three thousand people lost their lives in New York, the Pentagon, and Pennsylvania -- 750 of them New Jerseyans.

1279410634145267712.text: As we continue the fight for racial justice and address the pandemic, I'll be thinking of the sacrifices that keep our nation safe. I hope you'll spend a moment to think of those who are in harm's way right now as we celebrate -- even if the celebration is a little different.

1279410633298063360.text: Many of us are spending today with our families, but we should take a moment to thank those who are away from their families serving our nation abroad. The men and women of our military are spending today keeping us safe.

1279410632106946561.text: And I want to take a moment to thank our military personnel who put their lives on the line for those ideals. Let’s all take a moment and say thank you to those that protect us and ensure the freedoms that our nation fought so hard for years ago.

1279410631146442752.text: I want to recognize the circumstances that surround this year’s celebration of the 4th of July. Our country is grappling with long overdue efforts to address systemic racism while battling a pandemic that has taken far too many lives.

983512910076022785.text: I thank General McMaster for his 34 years of service to our country, and with his departure, the rest of us will have to work doubly hard to secure our nation’s future. (7/7)

983512852601425920.text: ...marks one of the most dangerous developments of the Trump Presidency. For my district in New Jersey that has a Joint Military Base and tens of thousands of active duty service men and women, we know what is at stake. (6/7)

983512802403979264.text: Having worked before at the White House National Security Council and the Situation Room, I know the critical role of the National Security Advisor, and I believe this transition between General McMaster and John Bolton…(5/7)

983512748779859968.text: While I was very critical of many of the national security decisions made over the past year, I felt better knowing that McMaster was in the Situation Room. Today now marks the first day of his successor John Bolton. (4/7)

983512590461689856.text: Some of my fondest memories were my lively discussions with him on the military base at the end of a tough day of work. I can only imagine how difficult this last year of his service was. (3/7)

983512516704833536.text: He was full of ideas and energy, always thinking of ways to improve, always in service of our country.  He also always engaged me and others with respect and camaraderie, even when we disagreed. (2/7)

983512401181102082.text: I worked in Afghanistan alongside General McMaster, and I want to take a moment to recognize his career following his final day of government service last week. I had the opportunity of working with McMaster in Kabul at our military headquarters several years ago. (1/7)
